DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility was sold on 12/22/2017. It is no longer a US Foods, Inc. Property

_prev_prog_3.Description:
US Food Service Baltimore
The following engineering and administration controls are in place to eliminate, or reduce the potential for an accidental release at this Facility.                      
(1)  Electronic Ammonia detection in the compressor room.                        

(2)The  Ammonia Monitoring system alarms if an an Ammonia leak occurs alerting pesonnel of a an Ammonia release.                                                     

(3) The detection system coupled with local security to alert designated plant personnel in the event of a leak during normal or off-shift hours.                     

(4) Detection system will activate compressor room ventilation  in the event a leak is detected.                                                                                                  

(5) High liquid level switches are installed on the recirculators that will shutdown the compressor associated with that vessel if a high level is detected by the vari-level system.                                                                                                

(6) Pressure relief valves are configured to all pressure vessels and compressor oil seperators to eliminate the possibility of an over pressurization condition within the vessel 

(7) A Mechanical Integrity Program/ Inspection Program is in place and supported by the maintenance staff and contractors to ensure the safe operation and integrity of the ammonia system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
US Foods Baltimore- The Facility is an operational food warehouse and cold storage. At this facility, we store various food products which are later distributed to restaurants and other customers. Like most cold storage warehouses, we use Anhydrous Ammonia in our refrigeration system.

US Foods Baltimore is commited to maintaining a safe manufacturing and food distribution environment. We are commited to  obeying local, state, and federal laws that apply to our business and ammonia system. To ensure compliance with EPA's RMP and OSHA PSM requirements, we have developed an extensive Process Safety Management System. Our priority is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia. The Facility Process Safety Management Program Includes the following  programs.                                                                                                                                                          

(1) Employee Participation:  We involve our employees at all appropriate elements of the program 
                                                                                                                                                                     
(2) Process Safety Information: We maintain the information relating to system design, maintenance, and ammonia exposure information.                                                                                                                                                             

(3) Process Hazards Analysis: We conducted a detailed PHA of the ammonia system to identify system hazards and potential operational problems. 
                                                                                                                                                      
(4)Operating Procedures: We provide written Standards of Operation for the ammonia system. These procedures help our staff ensure the ammonia system opearates within the designated safe limits.      

(5) Mechanical Integrity: We h

ave established a comprehensive program of inspecting and preventative maintenance utilized by our maintenance staff and contractors.    

(6) Training: Our employees and maintenance staff are trained in safe opearation of the ammonia system and the emergency response procedures to be follow in the event of a release.  

(7) Management of Change: The MOC Process ensures that any design changes or modifications to the ammonia system are formally reviewed to ensure they are within the safety design specifications.   

(8) Pre Startup Safety Review: Any system change or modification that could have an impact on the ammonia system safety is evaluated after installation using the Pre Start Up Safety Review Process.    

(9) Contractors: Contractors working at the Facility  are evlauated to their previous safety performance. All contractors receive a Facility Orientation to the hazards of ammonia and emergency procedures. Those contractors that are working on the ammonia system or could impact the safety of the system receive additional training on the facility work practices and procedures.  

(10) Hot Work pemits: At the facility we followed the Hot Work Permitting Process for all spark or flame producing operations. 

(11) Emergency Response: To ensure the safety of our employees, contractors, and the general public we have developed an emergency action plan. The facility coordinates emergency response with the fire department.   

(12) Incident Investigation: All incidents are investigated to determine the incident causes so corrective actions can be identified and improvements made.   

(13) Aproximately every three years we conduct a compliance assessment of our PSM Program to determine those program elements which need improvement and to verify compliance to the program.  

(14) Trade Secrets: Our Trade Secrects Program is maintained for 
compliance.

As stipulated by 40 CFR Part 68.25(b)(1), the "worst case" and "alternative case" hypothetical ammonia release scenarios were calculated and the results are on file at the facility and have been submitted to EPA in accordance with applicable requirements.                                                                                                    

We used the EPA's refrigeration guidance documents to estimate hazard levels (see the Risk Management Plan) available from the EPA , for details on the offsite impacts: due to National Security concerns, the US Government has advised the regulated community not to disclose the actual numerical data in this Executive Summary.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            

No Accidental releases of Ammonia have occurred in the past five years
